review.title: An Introduction to Logics of Knowledge and Belief
review.abstract: This chapter provides an introduction to some basic concepts of epistemic logic, basic formal languages, their semantics, and proof systems. It also contains an overview of the handbook, and a brief history of epistemic logic and pointers to the literature.

sections.heading: 1.2.5 Axiomatisation
sections.text: In this section we will discuss a form of thinking in which a conclusion is drawn purely on the basis of its syntactic form. Although there are several ways to do this, in epistemological logic the most popular method of defining deductive conclusions is the definition of an axiom system in the style of Hilbert. Such systems offer a very simple idea of formal proofs. Some formulas are only valid because they have a certain syntactic form. These are the axioms of the system. The rules of the system state that one can conclude that a formula is valid because other formulas are valid. A formal proof or derivation is a list of formulas in which each formula is either an axiom of the system or can be obtained by applying a system follow-up rule on formulas previously appearing in the list.

sections.heading: 1.4 Notes
sections.text: Two texts on epistemic logic by computer scientists were published in 1995: one by Fagin, Halpern, and Vardi (1995), and the other by Meyer and van der Hoek (1995). Another influential text on epistemic logic, which focuses more on philosophical aspects, is by Rescher (2005). Formal treatments of the concept of knowledge in artificial intelligence, especially for thinking about actions, go back to the work of Moore (1977). In the mid-1980s, the Conference on Theoretical Aspects of Reasoning in Literature, which was later renamed "Theoretical Aspects of Rationality and Knowledge," became the Conference on Logic and Decision Theory of Game and Decision Theory (LOFT) in the mid-1990s.

metadata.abstractText: This chapter provides an introduction to some basic concepts of epistemic logic, basic formal languages, their semantics, and proof systems. It also contains an overview of the handbook, and a brief history of epistemic logic and pointers to the literature. 1.
